awd_titl_txt: Data-Driven Learning and Geometric Embedding for Reduction and Control of Complex Heterogeneous Networks
awd_abstract_narration:
Complex systems in which multiple agents (components) affect each other dynamically are prevalent in nature and human society in different scales, such as neurons in the brain, bees in a hive, and human beings in a social network. Undesirable behavior of such systems, in the form of disease, economic collapse, rumor spreading, and social unrest, has generated considerable interest in understanding the dynamic structures of such complex networks and devising ways to control them. Despite the abundance of data, ease of access, and advances in data science, obtaining reliable models of such networks remains a very challenging problem. The scale of these emerging complex systems also poses a great difficulty. These obstacles also form a bottleneck for analyzing and engineering the dynamic structures (e.g., synchrony and clustering) and for controlling the collective behavior in such complex networks. This project will develop a unified data-driven framework to investigate fundamental questions regarding how to extract dynamics of a large-scale complex system or network from its simulation or measurement data, and how to control this system if the dynamics reconstruction is successful and reliable. The project will also support new initiatives to promote interdisciplinary education for students from traditionally underserved populations in local high schools in the city of St. Louis, MO, through the creation of summer research opportunities.

By bridging systems and control theory with concepts and methods from algebraic geometry, time-series analysis, and machine learning, a unified data-driven framework will be established. Specifically, a novel approach based on spectral decomposition will be developed to extract the dynamics of a complex system and decode the topology of a complex network using its time-series data. The properties of the reconstructed network, e.g., connectivity and the coupling strength of nodes, will then be utilized to synthesize a dynamically-proximate reduced network that is tractable for control-theoretic analysis and design. Furthermore, novel topological and geometrical approaches will be derived to construct local and global embedding of high-dimensional data to low-dimensional manifolds, which will reveal hidden topological structures in large data sets and characterize transitions of flow of the underlying dynamical system. In collaboration with researchers in biology and chemistry, the network inference, dimensionality reduction, and control techniques will be applied to a diverse set of complex systems from cells to societies, for example, for decoding functional connectivity in cellular networks and analyzing social synchronization in groups of animals.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Inferring time-varying topology from measurement data is an essential but difficult step towards understanding large, complex and diverse systems, e.g., biological, financial, social, and electrical networks. This network inference problem is challenged by the tremendous scale of the network system and the inherent nonlinearity within and between individual units, which in turn forms a bottleneck for analyzing and engineering the dynamic structures, e.g., synchronization, and controlling the collective behavior in such complex networks. This project develops a unified data-driven approach to efficiently and reliably inferring time-varying topology of complex networks and learning reduced, representative mathematical models that describe the network dynamics. 

Integrating tools of spectral decomposition and physics-based mean-field techniques, the large-scale, highly nonlinear topology estimation problem of complex networks is decoded into a linear inverse problem in a form suitable for implementation in a parallel computation architecture. In addition, the notion and quantification of dynamic modes for time-series data is introduced and adopted to develop topological data science methods for extracting hidden topological structures in big data and discovering transitions of flow of the underlying dynamical system. The established data-enabled methods substantially advance our understanding of dynamic complex networks ubiquitous in nature and engineering domains, and contribute to push the envelop of modern systems theory and computational engineering and learning through investigating emerging systems of tremendous scale.

In addition to systems and control, this project leads to new developments and enables diverse applications in data science, machine learning, neuroscience, and biology. It also enhances the infrastructure for research and education across these disciplines by merging data-driven and model-based approaches. The research products and outcomes have been disseminated broadly to these scientific communities through publications, presentations at conferences, invited lectures and colloquia, and distributed public software to engage researchers around the world in this exciting interdisciplinary domain.

Multiple workshops, mini-symposia, as well as invited sessions in international conferences on the topics of control and learning for dynamical systems have been organized by the PI in the control systems and applied mathematics societies. Efforts have been made to attract under-represented minorities and women to our research program. Independent study courses on special topics of control, computation, and learning of high-dimensional large-scale systems have been created and taught by the PI at Washington University in St. Louis. The outreach effort is also continued to actively engage general public and pre-college K-12 students in scientific research through the university's science outreach and summer research programs.
